sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for ʔ-k-l inflection: 3sg.m in pfv(full form)

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found
updating references to Zotero IDs via update-bibl-refs.xsl

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Very old speakers (70+) sometimes use kila-yākul and čila-yākul, in variation with ʔakal - yākul. Old speakers use all the aforementioned reflexes, except for čila - yākul.
Very old speakers (70+) sometimes use kila-yākul and čila-yākul, in variation with ʔakal - yākul. Old speakers use all the aforementioned reflexes, except for čila - yākul.

One 73 year old speaker from Karantina used kila-yōkil. In general very old speakers (70+) sometimes use kila-yākul and čila-yākul, in variation with ʔakal - yākul. Old speakers use all the aforementioned reflexes, except for čila - yākul.
Pickett (2005:243) notes that: "The consistent affrication of k in the perfect forms of the verb 'to eat' is another clear feature. So, xaḏa (he took), xaḏēt (you, m.s. took), čala (he ate), etc.

Pickett (2005:104) notes that: "In the imperfect such verbs conjugate as typical hamza-initial verbs, including the expected hamza elison; thus yākil (he eats), and yāxuḏ (he takes), etc. The imperfect does not essentially differ from tribe to tribe and it is the perfect, as well as the imperative, that acts as a clear dialect marker.
Pickett (2005:243) notes that: "The consistent affrication of k in the perfect forms of the verb 'to eat' is another clear feature. So, xaḏa (he took), xaḏēt (you, m.s. took), čala (he ate), etc.

Pickett (2005:104) notes that: "In the imperfect such verbs conjugate as typical hamza-initial verbs, including the expected hamza elison; thus yākil (he eats), and yāxuḏ (he takes), etc. The imperfect does not essentially differ from tribe to tribe and it is the perfect, as well as the imperative, that acts as a clear dialect marker.

Pickett (2005:104) notes that: "In the imperfect such verbs conjugate as typical hamza-initial verbs, including the expected hamza elison; thus yākil (he eats), and yāxuḏ (he takes), etc. The imperfect does not essentially differ from tribe to tribe and it is the perfect, as well as the imperative, that acts as a clear dialect marker.
Pickett (2005:243) notes that: "The consistent affrication of k in the perfect forms of the verb 'to eat' is another clear feature. So, xaḏa (he took), xaḏēt (you, m.s. took), čala (he ate), etc.

Pickett (2005:104) notes that: "In the imperfect such verbs conjugate as typical hamza-initial verbs, including the expected hamza elison; thus yākil (he eats), and yāxuḏ (he takes), etc. The imperfect does not essentially differ from tribe to tribe and it is the perfect, as well as the imperative, that acts as a clear dialect marker.
In al-Qaṣīm the realization is ʔakal
When unstressed, the initial a- can be dropped
Deducted from example
for the perfect form Leitner (2022) also attests kəla
Deducted from examples
Maltese orthography: kiel
Benkato (2014) attests kilā in the perfective
yākul occurs in the construction "yākul luḳ": he eats for you.
deduced from xḏāt "she took"
Deduced from xḏā "he took"
perfective is not indicated
perfective NOT INDICATED!
